awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Lightweight Adaptive Algorithms for Network Optimization at Scale towards Emerging Services
awd_abstract_narration:
The past decade has witnessed enormous transformations of information technologies. The era of cloud computing transformed how information is delivered.  With more and more devices becoming ``smarter'' and ``plugged'' into the Internet (through embedded microprocessors and communication chipsets), we are entering into a new era of ``Internet of Things'' (IoT) and cyber-physical systems where the cyber world and physical world are increasingly integrated through a variety of sensors and actuators that are planted into the physical world but controlled through the cyber world. Both today's cloud services and emerging IoT applications alter the point-to-point communication paradigm of the existing IP Internet architecture, and require increasingly demanding quality-of-service (QoS) requirements. These requirements call for scalable and intelligent network algorithms for controlling and coordinating various network components and managing and optimizing resource allocations, with capabilities 1) to meet ever stringent availability, reliability and QoS  requirements demanded by emerging services; 2) to cope with the enormous complexity of networked systems; 3) to effectively exploit the rich diversity and redundancy inherent in such complex systems as well as the new capabilities offered by new networking architectures and technologies.  

This project puts forth a three-plane view of networking as a conceptual framework to structure network functions and guide us in the network algorithmic designs for timely, resilient and resource-efficient information delivery: 1) an information plane capturing application semantics and requirements; 2) a (logically) centralized control plane; and 3) a distributed (programmable) communication (data) plane. This project postulates two design principles and challenges in network algorithms: a) the need for co-design of centralized and distributed network algorithms that can take advantage of a centralized control plane with a global view of the network state, while also enabling the distributed (programmable) network elements to make fast and intelligent decisions to adapt to the changes in the network conditions (e.g., failures); and b) the need for just-in-time (near) optimality as a key metric to gauge and guide the design of network algorithms for timely, resilient and resource-efficient information delivery.  The goal of the proposed project is to develop scalable, lightweight, and adaptive algorithms for scalable and intelligent network control and optimization. 

The research on new network algorithms will contribute to the development of new networking technologies. The project will actively involve undergraduate students - especially female students and underrepresented minorities in the research project, e.g., via NSF REU grants as well as senior design courses and the Undergraduate Research Opportunity Programs at the PIs' institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The past decade has witnessed enormous transformations of information technologies. With more and more devices become ``smarter'' and ``plugged'' into the Internet (through embedded microprocessors and communication chipsets), we are entering into a new era of ``Internet of Things'' (IoT) and cyber-physical systems where the cyber world and physical world are increasingly integrated through a variety of sensors and actuators that are planted into the physical world but controlled through the cyber world. Both today's cloud services and emerging IoT applications alter the point-to-point communication paradigm of the existing IP Internet architecture, and require increasingly demanding quality-of-service (QoS) requirements. These call for scalable and intelligent network algorithms for controlling and coordinating various network components and managing and optimizing resource allocations, with capabilities 1) to meet ever stringent availability, reliability and QoS  requirements demanded by emerging services; 2) to cope with the enormous complexity of networked systems; 3) to effectively exploit the rich diversity and redundancy inherent in such complex systems as well as the new capabilities offered by new networking architectures and technologies. 

This project puts forth a three-plane view of networking as a conceptual framework to structure network functions and guide us in the network algorithmic designs for timely, resilient and resource-efficient information delivery: i) an information plane capturing application semantics and requirements; ii) a (logically) centralized control plane; and iii) a distributed (programmable) communication (data) plane. This project postulates two design principles and challenges in network algorithms: a) the need for co-design of centralized and distributed network algorithms that can take advantage of a centralized control plane with a global view of the network state, while also enable the distributed (programmable) network elements to make fast and intelligent decisions to adapt to the changes in the network conditions (e.g., failures); and b) the need for just-in-time (near) optimality as a key metric to gauge and guide the design of network algorithms for timely, resilient and resource-efficient information delivery. 

The outcomes produced in this project include 1) quantitative models for understanding the key network elements, and precomputation of optimal resilient communication graphs to meet stringent availability, reliability and QoS requirements; 2) novel adaptive distributed control algorithms for multi-source, multi-destination information delivery meeting all the requirements of resiliency and QoS constraints; 3) fundamental sampling techniques to design scalable and lightweight just-in-time network algorithms with theoretical performance guarantees; and 4) implementation  using software-defined networking (SDN) and applications to emerging 5G and Next-Generation (NextG) networks. With the society’s growing dependence on cloud services and with the emergence of “Internet-of-Things” and various cyber-physical systems – thus inter-dependence among critical infrastructures – the premium placed on network capacity, resiliency and timely information delivery becomes ever higher. These complex systems comprise vastly diverse arrays of hardware and software components; managing them involve enormous complexity. The research advanced will not only contribute to the development of new networking architectures and technologies, but can also bring broader societal benefits.

This research project has also provided both undergraduate and graduate students with hands-on experiences in network designs and system development. In particular, several undergraduate students participated in this research project. The research team have incorporated the research outcomes in classroom teaching and course projects as an example of new routing approaches to encourage students to think “out-of-the box,” and as course projects for students to gain valuable “hands-on” protocol design experiences.
